a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a = tan (20 * pi / 180)"
and h1 : "b = tan (40 * pi / 180)"
shows  "a + b + sqrt 3 * a * b = sqrt 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ.\] The final Answer is \sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 From the angle addition formula, \begin{align} \tan 60^\circ &= \tan (20^\circ + 40^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ}{1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ}, \end{align}so \begin{align} \tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ &= \tan 60^\circ (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\
 &= \sqrt{3} (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a = tan (20 * pi / 180)"
and h1 : "b = tan (40 * pi / 180)"
shows  "a + b + sqrt 3 * a * b = sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that $a = \tan(20\pi/180)$ and $b = \tan(40\pi/180)$, prove that $a + b + \sqrt{3}ab = \sqrt{3}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ.\] The final Answer is \sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 From the angle addition formula, \begin{align} \tan 60^\circ &= \tan (20^\circ + 40^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ}{1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ}, \end{align}so \begin{align} \tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ &= \tan 60^\circ (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\
 &= \sqrt{3} (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Prove that the sum of the tangent of 20 degrees, the tangent of 40 degrees, and the square root of 3 times the product of the tangent of 20 degrees and the tangent of 40 degrees equals the square root of 3.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. tan x = tan (rad_of x)"
and h1 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ.\] The final Answer is \sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 From the angle addition formula, \begin{align} \tan 60^\circ &= \tan (20^\circ + 40^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ}{1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ}, \end{align}so \begin{align} \tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ &= \tan 60^\circ (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\
 &= \sqrt{3} (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. tan x = tan (rad_of x)"
and h1 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If $tan(x) = tan(rad(x))$ for all $x$, and $tan(20) + tan(40) + \sqrt{3} * tan(20) * tan(40) = \sqrt{3}$, then show that $\sqrt{3} = tan(20) + tan(40) + \sqrt{3} * tan(20) * tan(40)$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "tan x = sin x / cos x"
and h1 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ.\] The final Answer is \sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 From the angle addition formula, \begin{align} \tan 60^\circ &= \tan (20^\circ + 40^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ}{1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ}, \end{align}so \begin{align} \tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ &= \tan 60^\circ (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\
 &= \sqrt{3} (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "tan x = sin x / cos x"
and h1 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: The tangent of an angle is defined as the sine of the angle divided by the cosine of the angle. Given this, verify that the sum of the tangents of 20 degrees and 40 degrees, plus the square root of 3 times the product of the tangents of 20 degrees and 40 degrees, equals the square root of 3.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = sqrt 3"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ.\] The final Answer is \sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 From the angle addition formula, \begin{align} \tan 60^\circ &= \tan (20^\circ + 40^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ}{1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ}, \end{align}so \begin{align} \tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ &= \tan 60^\circ (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\
 &= \sqrt{3} (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. tan x = sin x / cos x"
and h1 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ.\] The final Answer is \sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 From the angle addition formula, \begin{align} \tan 60^\circ &= \tan (20^\circ + 40^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ}{1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ}, \end{align}so \begin{align} \tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ &= \tan 60^\circ (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\
 &= \sqrt{3} (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. tan x = sin x / cos x"
and h1 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given that the tangent of an angle $x$ is defined as $\frac{sin x}{cos x}$, show that $tan 20 + tan 40 + \sqrt{3} * tan 20 * tan 40 = \sqrt{3}$. The final answer is $\sqrt{3} = tan 20 + tan 40 + \sqrt{3} * tan 20 * tan 40$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 20"
and h1 : "y = 40"
and h2 : "tan (x) + tan (y) + sqrt(3) * tan (x) * tan (y) = sqrt(3)"
shows  "sqrt(3) = sqrt(3)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ.\] The final Answer is \sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 From the angle addition formula, \begin{align} \tan 60^\circ &= \tan (20^\circ + 40^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ}{1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ}, \end{align}so \begin{align} \tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ &= \tan 60^\circ (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\
 &= \sqrt{3} (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 20"
and h1 : "y = 40"
and h2 : "tan (x) + tan (y) + sqrt(3) * tan (x) * tan (y) = sqrt(3)"
shows  "sqrt(3) = sqrt(3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. tan x = sin x / cos x"
and h1 : "tan (20 * (pi / 180)) + tan (40 * (pi / 180)) + sqrt 3 * tan (20 * (pi / 180)) * tan (40 * (pi / 180)) = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = sqrt 3"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ.\] The final Answer is \sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 From the angle addition formula, \begin{align} \tan 60^\circ &= \tan (20^\circ + 40^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ}{1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ}, \end{align}so \begin{align} \tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ &= \tan 60^\circ (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\
 &= \sqrt{3} (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. tan x = sin x / cos x"
and h1 : "tan (20 * (pi / 180)) + tan (40 * (pi / 180)) + sqrt 3 * tan (20 * (pi / 180)) * tan (40 * (pi / 180)) = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given that the tangent of an angle is equal to the sine of the angle divided by the cosine of the angle, find the value of $\tan(20^\circ) + \tan(40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \cdot \tan(20^\circ) \cdot \tan(40^\circ)$. The final answer is $\sqrt{3}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. tan x = sin x / cos x"
and h1 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ.\] The final Answer is \sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 From the angle addition formula, \begin{align} \tan 60^\circ &= \tan (20^\circ + 40^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ}{1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ}, \end{align}so \begin{align} \tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ &= \tan 60^\circ (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\
 &= \sqrt{3} (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. tan x = sin x / cos x"
and h1 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that $tan(x) = \frac{sin(x)}{cos(x)}$, show that the equation $tan(20) + tan(40) + \sqrt{3} \cdot tan(20) \cdot tan(40) = \sqrt{3}$ holds.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. tan x = sin x / cos x"
and h1 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ.\] The final Answer is \sqrt{3}
 ### Proof
 From the angle addition formula, \begin{align} \tan 60^\circ &= \tan (20^\circ + 40^\circ) \\ &= \frac{\tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ}{1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ}, \end{align}so \begin{align} \tan 20^\circ + \tan 40^\circ + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ &= \tan 60^\circ (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\
 &= \sqrt{3} (1 - \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ) + \sqrt{3} \tan 20^\circ \tan 40^\circ \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. tan x = sin x / cos x"
and h1 : "tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40 = sqrt 3"
shows  "sqrt 3 = tan 20 + tan 40 + sqrt 3 * tan 20 * tan 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If $tan(x)$ is defined as $\frac{sin(x)}{cos(x)}$, prove that $\sqrt{3} = tan(20) + tan(40) + \sqrt{3} * tan(20) * tan(40)$.
